Posts.Content: Hi Connie1993 welcome to the forum. I am so very sorry to hear about all that has gone on for you and appalled at what is happening for you. Too young?????? How dare they if they have confirmed that you have that gene then you should be being offered options and not just told we will see you when you are 30. There are two  things you could do right away. 1) Make a complaint about the way you are being treated and how closed a mind your Oncologist has had with you. The hospital must have a complaints department and I would put pen to paper now and get that sent in.   2) You could contact the MacMillan Line in the am or until 8pm tonight and ask for their advice I feel sure they will be able to offer you some support to move this forward for you. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and we will be here for you as long as you need us to be. Meantime im sending you some huge big hugs. xxxxx

Ho walkkt welcome to the forum.and yes you are in the right place it's hard seeing your friend struggling but it sounds like you are a really good friend already just keep being there for her and be kind to you as well as it can be hard supporting someone with csncer so look after you as well. please keep in touch and let us know how your friend is doing in the meantime here are some huge virtual hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: Advise for a friend of a breast cancer sufferer

Posts.Content: Hi Last71 sending some more big hugs to show you that you are alone on this journey. xxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: The waiting is getting me down

Posts.Content: Hi Charlie brown welcome aboard the roller coaster which is breast cancer! it feels like everything comes at once and it is easy to feel overwhelmed by it all! My breast cancer was invasive lobular and oestrogen + and I'm out the other side so it is doable and treatable and you will be closely monitored afterwards for 10 years I'm not saying it's an easy journey because it's not but you do come out the other side intact but changed as a person especially on your Outlook on life please let us know how you get on and sending big hugs your way xxxx
Posts.Title: Waiting for MRI invasive lobular cancer ER+

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz18 welcome to the forum and you will be scared right now as there is a lot of uncertainty until all the results are back and then they can make a decision with you as to the next step. My Breast Cancer was the same type as yours and I am nearly on my second follow up mammogram so it is doable it is hard Im not going to lie to you and your emotions may be all over the place but you will come out the other side. It will be amazing how you cope I was amazed at how I did it as well but I did and Im out the other side its amazing what inner strength we all have that we can draw on when we need to and you will have that as well. You will be in shock and that is perfectly normal and also very ok it will pass as the news begins to sink in then you will get a second wind and the fight response will kick in and you will do all that you can to beat this beast and we will be here with you every step of the way so you will not be alone. Sending some huge big hugs meantime and if you have any questions happy to answer as best I can. xxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Hormone positive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Addison welcome to the forum. Sometimes it has been known for Mammograms to not pick up things but as far as I know it is rare for that to happen. Breast Cancer doesn't always run in families I have none in mine either but still got it it doesn't discriminate unfortunately and often strikes when we least expect it and catches us on the back foot. Dropping the anger is good but you need to maybe drop also that search for 'why', because there isn't an answer and you will drive yourself mad looking for one and blame yourself for something that is so random none of us know which one of us it will strike and we have no control over.  They wont know many of the details until the area is out and sent to pathology who do the staging etc and then you will know exactly what you are dealing with and what treatment they are proposing for you. It sound to me like you are one feisty lady pushing them to re-scan and catching things as they did good on you for doing that many people don't always feel able to do that. It is a scarey time for you right now but we will be with you every step of the way so you wont go through any of this alone. Im not sure about the choice but its good that there was one as if they had thought it was so bad they would have opted right away for a full mastectomy so there is some positive in there. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on as we will be thinking of you. Meantime Im sending you some huge big hugs. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer, having surgery Monday.

Posts.Content: Hi Mariana welcome to the forum. I cant believe that you are having to deal with all this at the same time. You will be reeling between trying to deal with all that has happened for you and then your husband leaving. There are no words.xxxx I dont know what to say to you except to let you know that we are here for you and even though you may feel alone you are not as we will be with you as much or as little as you like to get support and someone to chat with  Sending some huge big hugs your way. xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: living alone with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz18 I had lobular in my right breast and had a lumpectomy and radiotherapy and now on hormone blockers. Don't look at Google I did that and nearly scared the life out of myself until I found here and been here ever since. This particular type of cancer doesn't grow in the same way as other cancers it grows length ways so they can't always see it all.They may not know for certain until they get it out the actual size because of the way it grows. Mine was double the size they thought but still very treatable and yiu will kick this beast in the arse as well xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Hormone positive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Lellyv welcome to the forum. What has happened for you with things being changed is not unusual at all. However, that does not make it any easier to accept that things have changed when you probably had only begun to get your head around what has happened for you. Yes people can and do work when having chemo but we all react differently so you will need to play that one by ear and take each session as it comes. As you are about to start a  new job on Monday could I suggest that you make contact with the Macmillan Line as there are specific guidelines about Cancer and the workplace and these may be helpful for your new Managers and the Macmillan Line have  a welfare  tem who can advise you. They are contactable everyday between 8am -8pm on 08088080000. Sending some huge big hugs your way and very best wishes for the start of the treatment xxx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer and chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Ginacarla an interesting topic and like you I have had the cipla brand a few times and they are awful for the side effects so you have my sympathy. I had asked a pharmacist colleague of mine why I couldnt get the same brand and she said that each chemist gets a delivery from a warehouse that uses a picker and so that meant that each chemist could in theory get a different brand so to ensure the same brand I would need to trail round about 10 pharmacies. So like you I have put up with god awful side effects for months now until recently when I had a strange experience. Hubby went to the chemist for me to pick up my prescription and phoned me to say that the pharmacist wanted to speak to me which I did. It said on my prescription I was to have the Accord brand but they were unable to get this and hadn't been for some time was there a brand that I preferred? Now that was a novelty!!! I have opted for TEVA  which they can get and have assured me that they will try their best to ensure I get this which I have for the last 2 times and I can tell you the side effects are definetely less and whilst still there nowhere near as debilitating.  I'm like you and have been told I could stop for a while but not keen to do that as I am not brave enough for that so just keep taking the pills. I wonder with all the comments on here if we could persuade Macmillan to help us to compile a letter to see if we can change this as as you say 10 years of this is not very encouraging? Sending very best wishes for now .xxxx
Posts.Title: battle of the letrozole brands

Posts.Content: hi aspen welcome to the forum and also the roller coaster you are now on its got the potential to make your head spin. I wish I had a magic wand and could answer all your questions but I don't unfortunately and I don't know that anyone will can answer for you in any definitive way all I would say is do what you feel able to do but listen to your body and rest whenever you need to sorry to not be much help but take care of you because that's what's important sending big hugs xxxcx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, chemo about to start

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief I understand from the report that Long term and Chronic conditions will be exempt from these changes. It is interesting to know that a prescription for Paracetamol for example from a GP costs £35 to the NHS when they can be bought for under £1 in any supermarket.  Im in Scotland where we get free prescriptions but the same plans are afoot already. I do agree with you though that there should be exemptions to this but from what I can see and read that will be the case. However, as you say it will depend on the way this is interpreted by NHS TRusts etc . It always amazes me that NHS Trusts have to save millions of pounds and often able to do some of that which makes me wonder what were they spending the money on when they can afford to save all that money? Sorry for going off tangent with my ramblings.xxx
Posts.Title: HNS England - Prescribing Restrictions on Some Over The Counter D...

Posts.Content: hi h81 first of all welcome to the forum nobody wants to be part of but when they do come in for a visit they find enormous love and support and I hope this will be the same for you. They will have a rough idea by the biopsy but I don't think they will know for absolute certainty until the lump is out and been to pathology but your treatment will be based on what they know already but whilst this has been shocking news for you and you will be reeling from it it seems it may be an early breast cancer and I understand completely treatable and curable so hang onto that throughout what will be a roller coaster ride for you. Keep in touch and please let us know how you get on. sending big hugs xx

Posts.Content: hi h81 first of all welcome to the forum nobody wants to be part of but when they do come in for a visit they find enormous love and support and I hope this will be the same for you. Posts.Title: Newly Dignosed

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie1974 welcome to the forum that nobody wants to join but when they do they find support and reassurance and plenty of people who understand . Your gp has done exactly the right thing in referring you to the breast clinic as that is where the knowledge and expertise that you need is. It could still be another fatty lump but you won't know unfortunately until you get to the breast clinic . Please stay OFF Google it is unreliable and if you feel anxious now that will only make you worse stay here where the info is reliable and the people at macmillan are great. If you wanted to talk to someone try the Macmillan phone line number on the bottom of this page they are great listeners. I sometimes wonder if our hubbbies take the head in the sand approach and convince themselves that it will be OK possibly because they are a wee bit anxious themselves.  The only thing I can say is try to keep busy it will make the time pass quicker and please keep in touch and let us know how you get on. In the meantime I'm sending you some huge big hugs xxxxx
Posts.Title: Refered to breast cminic

Posts.Content: Hi dreamtheif you are an absolute star thank you for doing this it will be of enormous help to everyone here xxxxx
Posts.Title: Abbreviations and Terminology Used For Everything BC Related - Indexed...

Posts.Content: Hi Sheenadam welcome to the forum and so glad to hear that at least the surgery part is past for you. You will be sore and as you say this is to be expected but it doesn't always make it any easier to deal with so hope you are managing the pain with some form of pain relief for you? Its difficult to say what the back pain could  be it could be the way they have had you moved around in theatre or it could be that it is the way you are holding yourself and believe me when you are sore like like then we do hold ourselves differently to protect our sore breast. Alternatively it could be that maybe you are sleeping more on your back at the moment and again that's possible as you try to get a comfy sleeping position after the surgery. Maybe it's worth giving this a couple of days and if this isn't easing off then I would pop along to the GP and get them to check this out for you just to put your mind at rest. Hope the recovery goes well and look after yourself. Sending some huge big gentle hugs for now. xx
Posts.Title: Back pain after Breast lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Tray46 and a sad but warm welcome to this forum. Sad because you have had to find us but welcome because we all know some of what will be happening for you right now. The size of your tumour would be a consideration I imagine as to whether you would have had a lumpectomy or a mastectomy. When all the results come back they are discussed by with a Multi Disciplinary Team and a plan is put together for you for any further treatment or none required and that is standard for us all. It sounds like the results were not all back hence the delay I imagine. That said it is probably better, but stressful I know to wait and then everything is back and a full picture can be put together for you. The waiting is the pits and none of us would tell you anything different I dont think, except to try as best you can to keep yourself busy until they do come back as you cant do anything in this time until they do. I appreciate what you husband is saying and most likely he is trying  to remain positive to keep you positive but Im not sure that you should be running back to work just yet as you have to recover from this big op and there are all sorts of feelings that go with what has happened for you as well.. Im not surprised you are upset the whole things sounds like it has come as a complete shock and you have had no time to get your head around what has happened for you. I assure you you are perfectly normal in that and  in time that will pass but for now you just need to take a day at a time and recover and get those results back and know exactly what they have said and then move forwards. I am under no illusion that my last sentence sounds simple but is not in any way simple and you have to take whatever time you need to feel better and not what others tell you you should do. There are lots of knowledgeable folks here on the forum and I feel sure that one of them will be along soon to offer some re-assurance for you and also to let you know that we are here for you whenever you need us to be. Meantime Im sending some huge big hugs your way. xxxxx
Posts.Title: DCIS & Masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi I-Love-everyone welcome to the forum. Like you I finshed my treatment in July last year and just had my first mammogram which came back all completely satisfactory. They did say it could take  a few weeks but my take on that was if it takes six weeks to come back to me then things musnt be too bad as if there was something they would have been in touch right away. Its a horrible time the waiting in the lead up to it and the waiting after it but we are being carefully montored year on year.  Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on meantime here are some huge big hugs for you. xxxxx

Posts.Title: Intermediate Onco result, chemo yes or no?

Posts.Content: Hi Youngatheart welcome to the forum and so glad at least one part of this journey is over for you with the op. As far as I remember they put a dye in before surgery and release this during surgery and it goes to the tumour as  a marker. They always test the Sentinel node first and again if I remember right if its not in that one then it hasnt gone to the lymph nodes at least thats how mine was. Like you I only have one wound and the next part will tell them the grade and stage of the lump and the node biopsy. This next bit is the pits waiting for the results the time seems to drag but it will be here before you know it. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and hope that you find lots of support here having joined the forum. Everyone is lovely and know exactly where you are coming from. Sending some huge big hugs meantime. xxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Sleepyhead you will be in shock and its not surprising but hey the other way to look at things is that at least you are not having to wait weeks to be seen. The waiting is awful and your mind goes into overdrive and you havent even had time to process whats happened to you.. It may yet be something to do with breastfeeding and your gp is on the ball for you.  Its sinking in whats happened and so quickly its liek somebody has picked youi up in a tornado and you cant get back to get your feet onto the ground but you will. Be kind to yourself.
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi Sleepy head and welcome to the forum. You are not selfish at all  you have come to the right place to talk and get your thoughts out on print where others can see them and try to help. Now breathe!!!! Otherwise you will drive yourself mad. You are scared and thats normal when anyone fnds a lump but please remember that not all lumps are cancer and hopefully yours will turn out not to be that either. However, if it does turn out to be that then breast cancer is totally treatable nowadays and many people go on to lead full lives after treatment. Thiursday will seem like an age away for you but i will come round and your gp has done exactly the right thing in referring you as that is where the knowledge and expertise is that you need. try to keep busy it will make the time pass quicker and please stay OFF ggogle as that will scare you even more and it is not reliable. Others will be along soon aas well to offer reassurance for you and someone is always here so keep posting as you feel able and keep deep breathing to reduce the anxiety Thursday unfortunately wont come any quicker. Enjoy time with those children of yours and plesae keep in touch and let us know how you get on as we will be thinking of you.. Sendign huge big hugs.for you xxxx
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Hi shirl3 please don't give up now the chemo and radiotherapy are to make sure all is blasted away I cant tell you about chemo as i didn't have chemo but did have 20 sessions of radiotherapy and you don't feel anything at all its not like chemo .Radiotherapy is not without its side effects the main one being tired and skin can become red but with advice from the folks in radiotherapy you should hopefully skip the worst of that. I get why you might think it would be best especially after your experience with chemo and of course no on can make the choice but you. Personally I took everything they threw at me to make this bloody cancer go away and stay away but everybody is different. please let in touch and let us know how you get on and sending big hugs for a speedy recovery for you xcx
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Nursenala welcome to the forum and glad that at least the surgery is past for you. Its a bit of an individual thing which I imagine is not of much use in response to your question.  2 weeks post surgery is a bit early I think to be considering a job where it is physical as you are still healing from the op and this can take some time to get back to any degree of normality for you to be able to do your job. Does your company have any policy on how much sick leave you are allowed? If it was me I would take as much as you can as you will be tired and dependant on the outcome of the pathology from those lumps and lymph nodes will determine the treatment plan for you. Maye when you have that treatment plan you might be in a better position to know what kind of treatment you will need and the timeframes for this. Dont underestimate what your body has been through and may still have to go through with treatment. Take it easy while you can and if you need more time off than is ok for your company please give Macmillan Line a call as there are special rules governing people in the workplace and Cancer. 08088080000. Sending some huge big gentle hugs for now. xxxxx
Posts.Title: how long off work after lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi SFGS29 so glad that at least part of the treatment is past for you. Im probably not the best person to ask about this as I don't take anything at all. Like you Im am very cautious about what I put into my body these days so don't take anything that hasn't been prescribed for me in the hope that my own immune system kicks back in again. I know it will take time but that's just my thoughts and I feel sure others will be along soon to offer their input re this as well. Hope the radiotherapy goes well for you and sending very best wishes for now. xxxxxxxxxxxxx

Posts.Title: Now got date for operation and I have some questions ....

Posts.Content: Hi Blot3 welcome to the forum. I hadn't heard that before reading this on here so it's an interesting thing to hear about. I've not known anyone taking supplements to protect the brain and Im really not sure if it does make a difference or not.  There are often many stories about Breast Cancer and some of them make sense but some are just scaremongering but I'm not sure about this one. However by me answering your post this will bump it up the list and hopefully someone  may be able to help with further information. If not I wonder if you might like to post in the Ask a Nurse section as they may have more access to relevant research which may be available re your query. Posts.Title: Brain protection

Posts.Content: hi laura Jane 779 glad to hear that your mum is through her op that's great news the oestrogen positive part means that the tumours are fed by oestrogen so I expect that she will be put on hormone inhibitors like tamoxifen or letrozole to reduce her production of oestrogen I'm not sure if progesterone positive is the same or not sorry!! in respect of her2 negative mine was her2 negative and as far as I know this means that the cancer is less aggressive which is good news hope that is of some use and hope your mum makes a speedy recovery big hugs xccc
Posts.Title: Cancer type?

Posts.Content: Hi Miduf welcome to the forum and so glad to hear that your treatment is completed and you are out the other side. I know where you are coming from about going back to work nothing will have changed but you have at least thats how I felt when I went back. The things that were important to you before may become less so after what you have been through. I was hattered ht eforst 2 eweks when I wnerback even on a phase retirn so be gentle withn yourself and rest up as you are able and please keep in touch and let us know how you are getting on. Best wishes for Monday. xxx
Posts.Title: After fighting breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi AnnJac you will be feeling kinda nervous I imagine so a warm welcome to this community. and your questions are not silly at all. I didn't have a mastectomy mine was lumpectomy with node removal but personally I went for front opening nighties but that's just me I imagine front opening pj's would be ok as well. They may give you exercises to do after the surgery and its so important that you do these as they will help to get movement back in the arm. You may have  a drain in to start with immediately after the op but different hospitals seem to do different things so you may not have this but its a possibility.   I'm not sure that you will have a catheter in when you wake but you can ask them about this when you go in. Hubby taking some time off is a great idea as you can concentrate on your recovery and be totally pampered for  a week. It will depend on lots of different  variables as to if 1 week might be enough but as you say 1 week may be more than enough for you to deal with so maybe play that one by ear. I love the last bit about some support briefs- is that a just in case buy???  We are here for whenever you need us and I will be thinking of you. Sending some huge big hugs meantime. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Now got date for operation and I have some questions ....

Posts.Content: Hi Bananabamps I think the best thing for you to do is go and see your Gp and see what they say. Breast Cancer is not unheard if in males but the Gp is really the best person to advise you but please do come back and let us know how you get on. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Lumps in chest?

Posts.Content: Hi Sqwaatz welcome to the forum I think you have answered your own question you know your body and if it doesn't feel right then it's right to get checked maybe take some questions you want to ask or take someone with you and don't let it being a male doctor put you off your body your life please keep in rouch and let is know how you get on will be thinking of you sending big virtual hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: Appointment tomorrow... Bit Nervy

Posts.Content: HiHelenM17 my radiotherapy was delayed as well because of breast swelling apparently when they do the ct scan if there are any changes in the shape of the breast which there will be in your case they can't do the planning as it is not accurate enough so they are doing the right thing but it can't be easy for you! do you need to get back to work or want to get back? if not I would take the time to recover and even when radiotherapy starts you could be tired as it affects everyone differently hope you are OK and let us know how you get on xxxx
Posts.Title: Planning CT scan for radiotherapy needs to be redone

Posts.Content: Hi Mygirls welcome to the forum and sorry to hear how worried that you are. Sometimes the images are not all that clear and they sometimes have to take them again and this may be what has happened for your mum. Hope you get the answers and that they get clear images. Sending very best wishes for now.
Posts.Title: Recall after 4th yearly momogram

Posts.Content: Hi DnA welcome to the forum and so sorry to hear of all the stress you folks are under in the waiting period for results. The waiting is the pits because your mind goes into overdrive and you convince yourself of the worst case  scenario and many of us do this so your wife is not alone in that but keeping busy is the only way I found to distract myself from the waiting game. Please tell her if you can gently to stay OFF the internet it is unreliable and each persons cancer is different to the others so the treatment plan will be devised which is unique to your wife and no one else although there may be similarities in treatment. Newspapers are designed to grab the headlines and sell plenty of newspapers and they often report on only the worst case scenarios but there are many many positive and good stoiries that never make the newspapers as they dont sell the newspapers the same. It is likely to be a rough few days for you both until Thursday comes but once you have the results you will have a treatment plan put in place and then you will know for certain exactly what you are both dealing with. Maybe for now its about keeping your wife busy and giving her plenty of hugs. Meantime I think you could do with some hugs as well so sending some for you xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Helping with waiting

Posts.Content: Hi EleanorNya welcome to the forum and your have come to the right place for support it is a sneaky cancer lobular as it doesn't present in the same way as other cancers hence the mri which is good as they have picked it up quickly and can treat it. It might mean another op for your mum but there is no reason that you will lose your mum I understand completely that you are scared it's a scarey time for you all but she sounds like she has a wonderful caring supportive daughter and you will get through this you did the right thing coming into the forum  and please keep in touch and let us know how your mum gets on sendING huge big virtual hugs for you both xxxx
Posts.Title: Lobular Breast Cancer - Concerned Daughter

Posts.Content: Hi Tigermum and welcome to the forum. So glad that surgery is over with for you one part of the journey down. Seromas can fill up really quickly and can be problematic especially in the early days after surgery and lymph node removal. Do you have a breast nurse that you can call at all? If so I would give them a  call and ask if someone can have a look at this lump for you it could be related to the surgery or another small seroma forming but until someone sees that and has a look you are not going to know that for certain. This would at least put your mind at rest. Please let us know how you get on and thinking of you. Sending some huge big hugs. xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Kim1983 welcome to this forum and so very sorry that you find yourself here. Im not surprised that you are scared but please remember that lots of breast cancers are treatable now and hopeully yours will be as well. Have they given you any details about what they want to do surgery chemo radiotherapy etc or is all that too much to take in at the moment? Please keep in touch on here as there are lots of us around who can support you through this and be with you and answer as best we can any queries or just simply listen while you sound of steam and all of those are ok. Sendign you some huge big hugs for now. xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Stage 1 grade 3 , 7mm lump terrified :(

Posts.Content: Hi Mrs50 welcome to the forum. Im not too familiar with chemo but I wondered if you knew that there is a chemo thread in this forum and if you wanted to post your question in there one of the lovely folks in there should be able to help you with more information. Sorry not to have been of more help but sending some huge big hugs your way for now.xxxx
Posts.Title: Temperature during Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Hate waiting sorry you are having problems but welcome to the forum and I feel sure others will be along to offer re assurance.I know it must be very difficult for you and it sounds like you have had conflicting information from different doctors.You are going to the right place at the breast clinic they are very skilled and experienced and please keep in mind it could be anything at this point before cancer.It is possible it could be mastitis or some thing else connected to breast feeding and breasts getting back to normal. I know it will feel like forever for you waiting until the 8th of February and we cam all relate to that as well it's the pits waiting. However it is 10 days away and you need to find something to fill that time otherwise you wil make yourself I'll it's really hard but please take care and keep in touch and let us know how you get on sending big calming virtual hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Waiting to be referred to breast clinic

Posts.Content: hi jdperry you are allowed a wobble we all get them but that just means you are perfectly normal. I'm doing OK had some breast lymphodema which is slowly going down and I'm going for my first mammogram follow up in January so fingers crost. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: Hi A68 welcome to the forum. So sorry that you have had this upset when you are on holiday and supposed to be chilling out. I had the same as you and got picked up from a routine Mammogram and until I got my results back I was in complete denial of anything being wrong as I couldn't feel or see anything so was quite ok about things. See my profile. I can understand how anxious you are and I wish I could offer complete reassurance for you but what I do know is that you are going to the right place to get the results back with people who know what they are doing and have all the knowledge and expertise you need to find out exactly what is going on. The breast surgery part may be what they call their breast clinic- ours is called Oncology services. Not sure which one is worse on the old nerves!!!!. I imagine that you are going on Wednesday to get the results from the biopsy they have taken and then you will know exactly what you are dealing with. Its awful the waiting but hey as I said you are most certainly in the right place with the right team if this does turn out to be something but it could also turn out to be completely harmless. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and we will be here for you if you need us but hopefully wont. You will,be in shock right now and thats perfectly normal. Im sending some huge big hugs and hope to hear back from after Wednesday. xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results and have had appointment letter .

Posts.Content: Hi anxious daughter have you seen the ask an expert part of this site as there is a radiotherapy section and they will reply. Did your post get cut off it didn't look as if you had finished it? hope you get some assistance with your Query xxxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy advice

Posts.Content: Hi Catlover53 so sorry to hear about how you are feeling and the decision you have to make. It can be really hard cant it making choices and it would be so easy for us if  others made them for us but we both know thats not how it works and unfortunately it has to be down to us in the end. Have you mentioned how you arm feels after the SNB this may be cording which can be troublesome but fixable  I developed Lymphodema in my breast after the SNB but now being treated for that and it is working to kick this old Lymph system of mine back into full operation. I imagine it is always a risk after this type of surgery but many people dont get get it and some do so no definitive answer to that one. The issue with the lymph nodes is complex and thats why they will be wanting to remove them to improve the chances of completely eradicating this disease for you. There is not right or wrong answer but you need to make the decision that gives you the best chance of beating this disease and none of us ever get any guarantees of recurrence it is something we all  fear but have to learn to live with and never lose hope. Sorry not to have been of much help but let us know what you decide to do and how you are getting on as we  will be thinking of you. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Ancillary node clearance have or not?

Posts.Content: hi jdperry it's OK to be scared and frightened but asking what you have done to deserve this the answer is simple you have done nothing except be selected randomly to get breast csncer there is no rhyme nor reason to it jd  why is this happening to me well I asked myself that and the answer -why not me I am no different to anyone else so why not me! will the fear ever really go away I don't know but I think there is always a part of that feel like that it's scarey and I don't know if that fear ever truly leaves you but hey let's look at the positives and that's what you need to focus on or you will go slowly mad the cancer is gone and with all the tests they do to us  we have to put our trust in them that they have done their jobs but nobody can ever give us a guarantee bur that could be said for many things in life. Life is so very precious my friend don't live it in constant fear enjoy life and take one day at a time I hope you will keep in touch in the forum and hopefully start to regain your life after cancer cos there is one waiting for you xx
Posts.Title: Can’t stop worrying

Posts.Content: Hi Beth Im replying to your post  which will bump it up the forum pages and someone will come along soon to help with some chat with you. Big hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Total mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Bonnie1978 welcome to the forum and so sorry to hear about how worried that you are. This could be connected to the post mastectomy pain syndrome but the best thing to do is to make an appointment with the GP and get this looked into for you. This could be absolutely anything but I Do understand the fear that this may be something more than just normal rib pain. I think we all have that fear and I'm not sure that it ever truly leaves is but most of the time these things are totally unconnected and turn out to be nothing to worry about hence why I think a trip to the GP to get some medical advice would be worth ti if even just to put your mind at rest.  Please come back and let us know how you get on and Im sure some hugs wouldn't go amiss so sending some huge big hugs your way for now. xxxx.
Posts.Title: Secondary Scare

Posts.Content: Hi MrsVdog welcome to the forum sorry that you have had to find us but also glad that you have as we are a supportive group and will be able to support you whatever the outcome for you. I like you have to be grateful for the screening programme I was certainly a bit older than you when picked up but I wouldn't have known there was anything wrong as I couldn't feel anything but a lump there was and yes it was Breast Cancer but hey I am a 18 months down the line and I am still here causing untold mischief and getting on with life as best I can. The lump that you may feel could be internal swelling and bruising if you think whats on the outside of us then think what the inside this could also  be some scar tissue forming around the area and this can feel lumpy as well so most likely to be that rather than anything growing as you are thinking.  Are you taking someone with you when you go to get these results? It is recommended that you do and believe me when I tell you that it is so worthwhile as often you may be so anxious and naturally so that you don't take everything in that they are saying but the other person can often remember  things that you don't..  Hope all goes well for you at the results appointment  and we will be here for you every step of the way if it turns out to be what they think to could be. Meantime Im sure that a hug wouldn't go amiss so sending some huge big ones your way. xxxx
Posts.Title: Just joined the start line!

Posts.Content: Hi blaster I don't know the answer to your question as I didn't have chemo! However I imagine your scalp will get itchy when the hair starts to grow back. My scalp is much more sensitive to perfumed things since radiotherapy and I was advised by my hairdresser to try baby shampoo and it's working scalp nor nearly so itchy .hope you get some relief and let us know if you come up with any solutions sending big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Head itching

Posts.Content: Hi Anaal try to get some sleep you need to rest and let your body recover .                                                          sending big hugs xxxx

Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results and have had appointment letter .

Posts.Content: Hi Trapin 1 welcome to the forum. I know people who are on an anti depressant and letrozole so there are certain ones that can be prescribed by the GP but best to ask them first and see what they say. Please do not take St Johns Wart unless you have consulted with the Oncology Team as this can interact with lots of other meds and can cause some problems. The other thing to do is if you felt  like it is to post your question in our Ask a Nurse section of this site as they may be better able to provide you with more information. Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: hi mimi567 the nurse who took your blood pressure on that side should be told that that is what you have been advised not to do my nurses told me to always tell them I'm not quite sure what the reasoning is behind it but there must be a reason I expect it must be very scarey for you and I'm not surprised that you are anxious but be kind to yourself this cancer thing is a really scarey time for you . i  didn't have chemo but know a lot of the ladies at the breast cancer support group have had the same with inflamed veins with chemo so it's not unheard of .take care of yourself and I'm sure one of the lovely ladies on here will be along to maybe offer more advice and plenty of hugs for you. x
Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Roche welcome to the forum you are right in what you say when you say what  a year you have had. First of all 3 weeks ago fr your op and going for radiotherapy is not a long time for you not just to heal physically but emotionally and mentally as well and that part can take  a bit longer. If you are able to take more time off then if i was me I would as you say yourself you are not sure if you are ready and whilst maybe going back would be a good thing in that it would keep your mind occupied, in another way it pulls you down as well as trying to deal with ongoing treatment. Only you can make that call unfortunately. How long does it take to heal? Well there is a question if ever there was One? How long is a piece of string is the answer. We all heal differently physically but the mental recovery from Cancer can affect us all in different ways and sometimes thats the bit that takes the longest. Dont push your self too hard you need to take whatever time you feel that you need. This beast of a disease comes into our lives completetly uninvited, turns our lives upside down then leaves we hope for ever. The lasting impression it leaves on us though is harder to deal with sometimes and again we all deal with that differently. Your body is telling you that you need to rest as you are so tired so listen to your body and your own thoughts and do whats best for you.  Meantime Im sending some huge big hugs for you.xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Brest cancer returned in other breast

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic I think anyone who has gone through what you have gone through have a right to feel happy and I for one am so pleased that you do feel that. It's hard I don't know if the fear of recurrence ever goes away for any of us but hey happy sounds good to me so dance like no one is watching kick up your heels and enjoy your new found happiness. Should you enjoy this happiness?  you definetely should go kick up them heels gal and enjoy you deserve it x sending sum big hugs although if your dancing enjoy big time xxxxx
Posts.Title: Anyone Feel Like This

Posts.Content: Hi Avi1776 welcome to the forum and so sorry to hear of the issues you are experiencing. It is completely understandable that you fear that it might be back but I'm not aware that any of those symptoms you describe are related to breast cancer at the start. What you are describing sounds like menopausal symptoms and the flushes and dryness are both common when they shut off our oestrogen. I wonder if it would be wise to make a trip to the Gp to discuss all this as there are others meds that can be given although I think most of them have similar symptoms but maybe worth a try xxxx sending some big cooling hugs xxxxx
Posts.Title: Why extreme flushes now?

I think there is an awake thread on this page if you feel like talking to someone during the wee small hours. Please let us know how you get on tomorrow. Sendign some huge big hugs for you. xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Results day tomorrow - both hopeful and terrifirf

Posts.Content: Hi scared girl 34 having boosters is normal I don't know exactly how they decide who  has them and who doesn't but I had boosters that said I couldn't tell you which ones were boosters as the treatment was no different to the rest of the radiotherapy except maybe a different machine. Hope that's useful and beSt wishes for the rest of your radiotherapy xxxxx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy boosters?

Posts.Content: hi Lisa at 4 days post op the light headidness is more likely to be related to the anaesthetic it can take a week or more to fully get out of your system I wish I could say something that would make you feel better about what's happened and happening for you its a real roller coaster you are on so be kind to yourself and cut yourself some slack and just tale your time in processing what has happened to you I promise you you are not alone and I feel sure that some of the other ladies will be along soon to offer support as well sending you big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Day 4 post surgery

Posts.Content: Thats it Winnie thank you so much. xxx
Posts.Title: Once treatment has finished..getting back “to normal “

Posts.Content: Hi Mob29 welcome to the forum and sorry that you find yourself here but hey you are in the right place for support and what you are feeling is perfectly normal. However define normal!!! I don't know if there is such a thing I'm not very good with insertING links but I'm sure one of the lovely ladies on here might be able to its an article by a psychologist about life after cancer and I'm sure you will resonate with everything he says. Cancer changes us all somewhat I think and we are never quite the same but often that's a positive thing because you start to focus on you your life and what's important to you and all the other crap that life throughs up at us becomes pretty unimportant in the big scheme of things. You will find the path that is right for you believe me you will but it will take time so don't be too hard on yourself cut yourself some slack and celebrate being a strong woman who has  survived cancer and if you can get through that you can survive anything. there is always somebody here to listen so please keep in touch and sending huge big hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: Once treatment has finished..getting back “to normal “

Posts.Content: Hi Anni69 I dont know the answer to your question all I do know is that Tamoxifen and Letrozol seem to be the drugs of choice for preventing any recurrence. I am not sure how we find out for sure.
Posts.Title: How to see if Tamoxifen is working?

Posts.Content: Hi Tc38 welcome to the forum and hopefully your time with us will be short. I  know it will be  very worrying for you waiting and wondering this time is a very challenging time as our minds go into overdrive. However, you are being sent to the right place for some answers at the breast clinci as that is where the knowledge and expertise is that your need to determine what if anything is wrong. Please stay off google as it is unreliable and not up to date and will end up scaring the life out of you maybe unneccassarily. i do hope that your stay is short  here and that the news for you is good but please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and very best wishes to you. xxxxx
Posts.Title: bubble type lump on nipple

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy543 welcome to the forum. You post struck a cord with me hence my reply. I have been having something similar and was on an Oestrogen based vaginal cream prior to the breast surgery and mine was er+ as well so cant use that now but the Nurse Specialist I saw has given me something else to try. Do you still have contact with anyone at the breast unit as they could maybe help with this if you discussed this with them I am sure they will have heard of this happening many times. Alternatively you could post your question in Ask the Nurse on the site as they may be able to answer with more details than I can. Its not nice bit it is related to our Oestrogen being switched off by the meds so dont put up with it see if you can see a lady GP and have a discussion with them. They may want to examine you just to rule out any cervix issues prior to putting you on anything. Hope you get it sorted out, x
Posts.Title: Pain during intercourse

Posts.Content: Hi Winky49 thank you for your kind response and I am so glad that you have felt positive benefit from the forum and the people in it they are all great and the forum is such a string link for people to know that they are never alone on their journey xxxc

Posts.Title: ESA and cancer treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredgirl its a  difficult one when we get pain after all that we have been through and our response is often to jump to the most sinister reasons that we can come up with and you are not alone in that. However, most of us will tell you that in 99.9% of these it turns out to be totally unrelated . Thes headaches could be being caused by anything it could be due to anxiety it could be due to the Herceptin or it could be just an every day headache or you could need your eyes testing as examples. Maybe a  trip to the GP to get checked out is in order just to offer some re-assurance for you if nothing else.  Sending you very best wishes for now. x
Posts.Title: 1 year since diagnosis,Headache help needed

Posts.Content: Hi Winky49 welcome to the forum. Yes tiredeness is a big issue for most of I think at least for a while. Im still tired easily yet almost 6 months after finsihing but the awful fatigue feeling goes and is replaced by a tiredness at least thats what happened for me. xxx
Posts.Title: Tiredness nearly three months after finishing Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Winky49 welcome back and so sorry to hear about the issues you are having with the Letrozole. I wish I could say it would get better but Im not sure if it does. I have been on them now almost a year and I feel like you with all the aches and pains and the different brands doesnt seem to make  a huge difference. I do know that some of the ladies on here have spoken with their GP or Oncologist and have had different medications prescibed but I understand that they all have the same side effects some better then others, some worse. I am so sorry not to be answering you with a more positive answer but these drugs do have all the side effects you describe and they can be very debiltating.  I feel sure all the other lovely folks on here will be along soon to see if they could maybe offer any advice or support as well. Sending very best wishes. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Aching bones with Letrozol

Posts.Content: hi chezeds I was post menopausal when they found my lump which was er positive and was using a hormonal vaginally cream but had to stop immediately diagnosed so I can empathise with what you are saying although periods for me ate a dim and distant memory! speak to your gp and ask if there is anything they could give you that might ease things it's awful having to travel so far have you heard of the she wee it's a portable urinal designed for ladies  sending big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Hrt

Posts.Content: hi chezeds I was post menopausal when they found my lump which was er positive and was using a hormonal vaginal cream but had to stop immediately diagnosed so I can empathise with what you are saying although periods for me are a dim and distant memory! speak to your gp and ask if there is anything they could give you that might ease things it's awful having to travel so far have you heard of the she wee it's a portable urinal designed for ladies  sending big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Hrt

Posts.Content: Hi Matohu welcome to the forum and sorry that you haven had a response to your post yet. In answer to your question I think we are all different and some experience fatigue and some of us dont its not an easy one to advise about. You will know it when it comes if it does because it will take the feet from you and you will feel as someone has pulled the plug out of the socket. If that happens listen to your body and rest as much as you can as this will be helpful in managing any fatigue. Drink plenty of water before and after the treatment as this helps to keep you hydrated.  If you are able to and need to take some time off work and rest this takes its toll on your body and can take upward of a year for us to get back to any degree of normality whatever normality is. Good luck with the rest of the treatment and please keep in touch and let us know how you are doing. Meantime Im sending you some huge big hugs. xxxx
Posts.Title: Tiredness/fatigue

Posts.Content: Hi jenjen30 it's good that you have family that are supportive but it's your body and your life so you push as hard as you have to and need to to get complete reassurance do what feels right for YOUxxxx
Posts.Title: Ultrasound cancer detection rate?

Posts.Content: Hi Pointer welcome to the forum and so sorry to hear your news. Im glad though  to hear that you weren't shocked sounds like you were prepared for the news but just look out for maybe feeling differently over the next few days. you may not but its just so it doesn't catch you off guard. Alternatively everyone deals with things differently and it may be that you will be absolutely fine and that's ok as well. Stage 1 and no lymph node involvement is good news and totally treatable and that's great news, nonetheless it still means an op for you so look after your self and please keep in touch and let us know how you are doing as we will be thinking of you and we are here anytime you want to chat or vent whatever you feel at that time. Sending some huge big hugs right back at you. xxxxx If you feel that you would like to talk to someone you can always contact the MacMillan Line on 08088080000
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Content: Hi jenjen30 I am not sure that I can truly answer your question all I can say is that my lump was not able to be felt and could be seen on mammogram but it was only after ultrasound that they were able to confirm that lump looked suspicious then I had a biopsy taken which confirmed their thoughts that said I can understand your worries and if you feel strongly about you should push to be seen again it's your body and you know it better than anyone xxxx
Posts.Title: Ultrasound cancer detection rate?

Posts.Content: Hi so very scared I don't know what to say to reassure you.I don't know what your system is like buy I would imagine that the NP at a breast clinic would know what they are looking for and what needs further investigation or not! I completely understand that you will be anxious but please take a deep breath and breathe! If you are still worried I would be tempted to see a gp for further reassurance hope you get on ok and please try and stay calm I know it's not easy but making yourself I'll is not gping to help sending big virtual hugs for you xxx
Posts.Title: Please help I am so scared

Posts.Content: Hi French welcome to the forum and I'm so sorry you feel alone however you have remedied that by being here because you are never alone on this forum and some of the other lovely ladies will be along soon as well. I can understand why you are worried and it could yet be scar tissue but having been there once already it's only natural that you will be worried. please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and there are plenty threads on here for you to have a smile and maybe even a laugh at times its surprising that in the face of great adversity we can still find time to laugh but we do sending you huge big hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: Lump in breast 2 years after lumpectomy, chemo and radio

Posts.Content: Hi Charlie1974 welcome to this forum.  i  realise that this must be a very difficult time for you all the waiting around but I wanted to say -- just breathe . You have had your mammogram and biopsies have been taken so there is no way of knowing what type of breast cancer you may have if indeed it does turn out to be breast cancer until those biopsies are back. You seem to be asking about mastectomies when the diagnosis is not yet known and you may be scaring yourself even more and  I completetly get that you are anxious and this is normal for us all at this stage. The only thing you can do at this point is wait until the results are in and then we will be here to support you in anyway we can but please stay OFF google it is unreliable and not indiviudalised enough and likely to scare you even more. I hope Im not sounding negative as I dont mean to be but I can tell you are scared and thats ok. Dont put anything into your head until you have had the results and you know exactly what you may be dealing with and we will be here with you and for you every step of the way. Sendign some huge big hugs for now. xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: What is the prognosis for inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Bluebell22 welcome to the forum and rant away as much as you like thats what we are here for. You are allowed to have down days so dont be too hard on yourself this journey can be bloody awful on occasions and you would not be human if it didnt get to at some point. You will be nervous and thats ok its allowed as well its the waiting and the wondering that I think gets to us all the most. Sending some huge big hugs for now and hope that tomorrow will be a brighter day for you.xxxxx
Posts.Title: Cheering Up

Posts.Content: Hi Ks96 welcome to the forum. Tamoxifen tends to be used in pre menopausal women and letrozole tends to be used in post menopausal women hence the check the Dr has done before starting these. Hope that is useful for you and hope you have lots of happy times with your girlfriend. Very best wishes to you. xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxafin Letrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Morgana17 welcome to the forum. I'm sure some of the lovely folks on here will be along to help as well but I can only tell you what happened at mine. You should get to know the type of breast cancer size any nodes involved or not and her 1 and 2 status and also oestrogen receptive or not. Based on all that information they should be able to give you  the treatment plan for you. I wouldn't want to speculate on what that could be as it will depend entirely on what the results show! Please keep in touch though and let us know how you get on and very best wishes for the appointment.Oh I forgot to say if you have any questions about anything write them down and ask them then also maybe take somebody with you as someone has already said two sets of ears are better than one xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Clinical Oncology

Posts.Content: Hi Rox good to hear all your useful tips for what worked for you it sounds like you have taken control of your situation and well done for doing that! I think two things helped me and both came from someone I knew who had already been on the journey and these are them 1) take one day at a time and live it. 2) When you start treatment take one bit at a time as thinking about it all at one go can throw you into overdrive. Both worked for me . sending big hugs xx
Posts.Title: Things that have worked for me

Posts.Content: Hi Trinity60 welcome to the forum and glad that things are beginning  to move forward for you in respect of starting chemo. Im wondering if you knew that there is a specific thread dedicated to chemo on this forum and lots of lovely folks in there who could maybe answer your questions and offer some reassurance and advice for you as well if you wanted to post in there. Sending some huge big hugs meantime. xxxx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy experience and advice as finding it difficult

Posts.Content: Hi ajlmay and  a warm welcome to the group although we always hope that no one ever needs to come here. You have taken the first step in reaching out and we will be here for you all the way as you need us to be. We are a friendly bunch though and try to support each other as much as we can.  I can totally understand why you are anxious about this as you have been in this situation before and any of us would feel the same in your situation, so you are not alone. You are doing the right thing though going to the GP and you are right in that they will possibly want you seen at the Breast Clinic. You wouldn't be human if you didn't feel nervous and past history is taking you to the bad place but again any of would feel the same and as you say this could well turn out yet to be nothing to worry about.  I wish I could say something to you to make any of this any better but you know the drill and tomorrow is the start of the process seeing the GP and getting expertly checked out. Will be thinking of you tomorrow and do please keep in touch and let us know how you get on as we will be thinking of you. I suspect that there may be a sleepless night ahead but hey tomorrow will be here before you know it. Thinking of you and sending some huge big hugs your way for now. xxx.
Posts.Title: Feeling nervous about gp appointment

Posts.Content: Hi ajlmay at least the outcome was kind of expected but upsetting nonetheless. Ah the keeping busy stage well the best thing to do is keep so busy with different things that you don't have time to dwell on any of it and when you go to bed you are so tired that you have to sleep. My house was begging me by the end of the waiting period to leave it alone as it was cleaned to within an inch of its life. There isn't an easy answer unfortunately but its ok to feel upset and scream and shout at the unfairness of everything  as much as you like. When you go to any of the posts there should be  a blue reply button and you just press that and start typing and then press send . If you want to start a new conversation at the top of the main page there should be wording that says "start a new conversation" and you press on that put a title in the heading ,start typing, then press post and your post should come up.  its ok to have a practice we are not in the least formal on here and as I said we are here for you every step of the way so keep in touch and keep super busy. When that thought comes into your head get up and do something and hopefully it will go away. Forgot to say that there is an awake thread in the Breast Cancer forum for the night owls so if you cant sleep and want to chat just go on there awake thread Just press the link I have included and it will take you straight there. Take Care and keep in touch and sending some huge big hugs your way. xxxx
Posts.Title: Feeling nervous about gp appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Gable girl welcome to the forum and thank you for sharing that tip it sounds like a good idea and if you got a nights sleep then that's even better .sending best wishes for a speedy recovery xxxx
Posts.Title: Sleep tip

Posts.Content: Hi Julesy1 that is fantastic news about your results. The Radiotherapy should be ok although it can make you very tired but that doesnt happen for everyone and you dont actually feel anything with Radiotherapy. It can affect the skin being treated though so look out for any redness and tell them right away. I hope that you get back to living life as before but I often wonder if any of us are every the same after Cancer it changes us in ways that we hadnt expected and leaves us thinking and feeling differently about things . I cant comment about Tamoxifen as I am on Letrozole but they do have their own side effects as well but all manageable and the folks on here have lots of tips and ideas about managing the side effects and I feel sure they will share these willingly with you. Sending some huge big hugs for now and please keep in touch and let us know how you are doing. xxxx
Posts.Title: Everything and the Big C

Posts.Content: Hi Littleone 31 welcome to the forum can i ask if it was an underwire bra that you were wearing at all as this might explain the bleeding if the underwire was pressing on the area under the breast? I think it might be expected to have some bleeding as the op was only Wednesday but not sure about that so think you are doing the right things and seeking advice on Monday. Sending very best wishes meantime. xxx
Posts.Title: Bleeding after op

Posts.Content: Hi Anonymous49 so glad that at least the op is over for you and you are in the recovery period. I know it may feel like a long time for you but 15 days is not really that long for the recovery and especially if you have a haematoma. It will go down but it will take time to do that. My friend has had a haematoma from a biopsy from her breast and it is only now going down after 4 weeks. Have you tried an  ice pack to see if that helps take some of the achy part out of it. If any of it gets hot or red you need to see the Nurse as that can be an indicator of infection. It is early days yet for you so take it easy and keep doing the exercises they gave you as this will help ensure that your arm regains full movement. In the meantime Im sending you some gentle hugs. xxxx
Posts.Title: Slow recovery from WLE and SNB

Posts.Content: Hi whathappened Leolady is having some time out just now.  She was an absolute star but time for her to take some time for her right now. xxxx
Posts.Title: Shout out to lovely Leolady56

Posts.Content: Hi Londongurl welcome to the forum. I dont know about Tamoxifen as I am on Letrozole and the side effects can be pretty grim but seems to get  bit better as time goes by. Are you being stupid not to give it a try? Everybody will have  a different opinion on that but none of their opinions really matter if it is  something that YOU feel comfortable about. Purely on a personal level I am not brave enough not to take them but thats me and not anyone else. Hope you manage to reach a decision that you are happy with. Sending very best wishes. xxxx
Posts.Title: Refusing Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn151 Welcome to the forum and I am sorry that I cant answer your query about the chemo unfortunately as I didnt have chemo. However I would suggest that you telephone the hospital or the chemo clinic over the weekend and ask them and or if you feel ok to wait until Monday. I think you really need them to check this out for you and reassure you.PLease let us know how you get on .xxxx
Posts.Title: Pain in arm chemo fec was given 9 dsys ago

Posts.Content: Hi Fiemans wife welcome to the forum and so sorry to hear about the fatigue that you are experiencing and I think personally that it is fatique and it has hit you with a bang. I remember mine hit me at exactly the same point as you that said you are a good deal younger than me but it is not pleasant and takes the feet from you. I'm not surprised that you are exhausted after all that you have been through your poor body has taken some beating and it will take as long for it to recover again. I think we all get tired when we have periods and add that to having radiotherapy at the same time and your whole body is being bombarded. Are you able to take any more time off until your Radiotherapy is completed? The reason I ask is that it can take it out of you and keeping ploughing through can lower your immune system at a time when you need it in tip top form and that leaves us open to silly bugs etc especially in the workplace. I think it is fatigue and all I can suggest is that you rest as much as you can and listen to your body and relax. The other thing to do is maybe ask when you go for your next Radiotherapy session I feel sure they will be well used with answering this question and can hopefully offer you some re-assurance. Drinking plenty of water before and after treatment helps a little as well. Meantime Im sending you some huge big hugs. xxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Fatigue?

Posts.Content: Hi Scd72 I would be tempted to phone your out of hour and seek some advice as it could be a build up of fluid or an early infection but I do think somebody needs to have site of it to offer you some re-assurance if nothing else. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on.Sending big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Swelling after drain removed

Posts.Content: Hi Cannykie50 welcome to the forum and so glad that at least the surgery is by with for you. It is common for things to be a bit tender for few weeks and as you say some of it may be the bruising coming out I would however be concerned if the breast felt hot to the touch or red looking and maybe itchy this can be a sign of an early infection which can happen. If you are worried at all then give them a call and they will see you earlier to check you out.   Hope the results are positive news for you an please let us know how you get on as we will be thinking of you. Sending some huge big hugs for now.xxxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Is this usual

Posts.Content: hi dormouse first things first you are not alone in having weird families we have a saying in scotland that there is nowt queerer than folk and it is so true secondly definetely speak to the oncologist about this when you see them and I douby that they will be there on 25th or 26th due to publc holidays sending big hugs and please do let us know how you get on xxx
Posts.Title: BRCA gene question

Posts.Content: Hi Kargus welcome back to the forum and so glad you have popped by. I am sorry to hear that you are so  worried about the results coming back so quickly and Im not surprised you are anxious I think we are all like that in the time that goes by between our diagnosis and follow ups etc. I wonder if your problems in the nether regions could be to do with the lack of Oestrogen?  I was on a hormone cream for dryness and had to stop it as my BC was Oestrogen positive and some days I could scratch myself silly. (Sorry too much information there). I know that my results came back really quickly but I think because of our histories they do speed up all these things for us so it may be totally innocent but I do understand completey your worry and fear. Please keep in touch and let us know how you get on and we will be thinking of you. Meantime sending some huge big hugs for you. xxxxxx

Posts.Title: tamoxifen problems

Posts.Content: Hi yeshh11 I'm sorry to hear that you are feeling sore! When you had the ultrasound and found the lump in your breast was this done at a breast clinic. Posts.Title: Painful Lymphnode (any advice appreciated)

Posts.Content: Hi Ludo and welcome to the forum. I noted that you had not had a reply so by me replying this bumps it up the ladder a bit and hopefully others will see this and respond with some advice for you. Like you Ludo mine was Lobular breast Cancer as well and like you I had all sorts of weird and wonderful sensations in the breast for at least a year after treatment ended but I am assured that this can be the case and that it is the nerves all healing and they dont always tell you that stuff so it is worrying. Im glad that you have been checked out and they cant feel anything but maybe they could do an ultrasound to see if there is anything there or if it is just healing maybe you could ask about that. In terms of bone scans I have one every year but not to check for Cancer but to check for any signs of  Osteoporosis as I am on Letrozole and that is known to have some of these issues for our bones. I'm not sure if that is of any help but I feel,sure some of the other lovely folks on here will be along soon to share experiences and hopefully offer you some reassurance.  Meantime Im sending some much needed huge big hugs for you. xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Dragging pain in breast/chest 3 months after radiotherapy ??

Posts.Content: Hi ShirleyJ welcome to the forum and I am so very sorry to hear that news about your mum and at such a young age as well that's awful. My response is in response to you saying you have found some pea sized lumps and think this is cysts. Well I agree, that this could be cysts but what is vital here is that you make  a GP appointment right away and get this checked out and it may be that they refer you further to the breast clinic and whist that might sound scarey they are the people that will tell you whether that is cysts or not after some tests.and full examination for you. My understanding of the Mammograms is that for the screening programme these start at aged  50. I am lead to believe that this is because the breast tissue at that age is less dense than when we are all younger but I'm sure some of the other lovely folks on here will pop along soon with some further advice.. However please do pick up that phone and make a GP appointment to get those lumps checked out by a medical professional.   Please come back and let us know how you get on. Im Sending very best wishes your way for now. xxxxx
Posts.Title: My mom died at 43

Posts.Content: Hi Haz2015 welcome to the forum that nobody wants to join. I dont believe that there is such a thing as a typical breast cancer lump they can be other things and the only way to know for certain is to go to the breast clinic and for biopsies to be taken if that is felt neccessary. I wish I could say something to reassure you but it really is a waiting game unfortunately until you get to the breast clinic. It is a difficult and scarey time for you and the waiting is the worst. Pleaase stay OFF google it is unreliable and not accurate as breast cancer is very individualised and google is very general. I hope it turns out to be something other than breast cancer but if it is it is treatable and many people go on to live fulfillig long lives. It could be lots of things though before that. Please keep in touch and let us know how you are gettign on and please feel free to keep talking if it helps there is always someone around. Sendign huge big hugs for you. xxx
Posts.Title: Worrying breast lump

That said I think you are doing  the right thing in contacting the Breast Nurse and I would keep trying until you get them as they can totally answer any queries that you have and also offer much needed re-assurance for you. You are not overreacting you are looking for answers and that  ok as well. Sending some huge big hugs your way for now. xxxx

Posts.Title: Waiting has never been a strength of mine!

Posts.Content: Hi Charlene70 welcome to the forum. The drugs you refer to are of the same kind of drugs designed to shut off oestrogen production. To my knowledge Tamoxifen is prescribed for women who are pre menopausal and letrozle for women who are post menopausal. I suspect that both drugs will have similar side effects and none of them are very nice but when your tumour is oestrogen positive Im too afraid not to take them but I think it is an individual decision possibly in discssuion with your Oncologist or breast nurse. Please let us know how you get on and what you decide..Sending you some hugs in the meantime. xx
Posts.Title: I am all mixed up - what's the difference between Letrozole and Tamoxifen...

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic so sorry you are feeling down I think we all get those days. I wish I could give you a timeframe when the thought of reoccurence goes but unfortunately I cant. Here are some hugs to brighten your day xxxx
Posts.Title: Down day

Posts.Content: Hi Oks welcome to the forum. I am so very sorry to hear about the problems that you are experiencing. Well done for getting through the surgery at least one part is past for you. Seromas often form after surgery and can take some weeks to rectify themselves and can often need draining unfortunately but they do eventually stop and then you can begin to heal fully. It is common to take the drains out at the time that they have but sometimes they leave them in for a bit longer but all areas seem to  be different with this. I am hopeful that maybe one of the lovely ladies on the Breast Cancer forum may be able to offer more advice re this for you and they will be along soon. Meantime Im sending some huge big gentle hugs your way.xxxx

Posts.Title: period

Posts.Content: Hi Jessief04 first things first welcome to the forum you have come to the right place for support and chat while you wait for that appointment. The fast track is put in place for the breast referrals and this is a standard target that is set by Governements. So that may explaine the quickness of the appointment. It sounds like the GP has written the letter and said what they suspect but they have to always suspect Cancer with lumps until proven otherwise so that may just be them being cautious. That said you are going to exactly the right place at the breast clinic as that is where the knowledge and expertise is that you need to determine exactly what those lumps are. Bringing someone with you is also advised as there may be lots of bits of info to take in so two sets of ears are better than one and If you are like the rest of us at these appointments you may be anxious and not take in all that was said perfectly understandable given where we are. If and it is a big if. If it is  Breast cancer it  is very treatable today and there is no reason to suppose that you will not see your children grow up in fact no reason to suppose that you wont be dancing at their weddings or cuddling your grandchidren. Its a scarey time right now for you all but just come on here anytime and get as much support as you need to get you through to that appoinrment. Please stay away from Google it is unrealiable and not indiviudlaised enough. Hang in there and sending you some huge big hugs for now xxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Back again

Posts.Content: Hi Matohu so sorry to hear about how you are feeling. If it helps to reassure you a lot of the feeling you are experiencing are normal for many of us but not nice just the same.  Yes you can be referred for Counselling and maybe your GP could do this for you or if you have a local Maggies Centre they may be able to offer this for you as well. There is an article by a Psychologist a Dr Peter Harvey and if you type in the name on the internet you will be able to read his artiicle and if you are anything like me you may recognise yourself in there and cut yourself some slack for the feelings you are having. Sending some huge big hugs for now. xxxxx
Posts.Title: Well that’s that
